passage_text: The average rate for a Licensed Vocational Nurse (LVN) in Los Angeles, California is $20.44 per hour. A skill in Acute Care is associated with high pay for this job. (United States). The average rate for a Licensed Vocational Nurse (LVN) in Los Angeles, California is $20.44 per hour. A skill in Acute Care is associated with high pay for this job. Most people with this job move on to other positions after 20 years in this field.

For example, BLS.gov data shows that LVNs in Salinas earn the highest average salary of anywhere in the country at $59,670 per year, just ahead of vocational nurses in the Bay Area (San Francisco, San Jose and Oakland in particular) who also average close to $60,000 annually. LVN Salary in California. If you’re thinking about becoming a Licensed Vocational Nurse, you’ll be interested to know that the average LVN salary in California is almost 10% higher than elsewhere in the United States according to www.BLS.gov.

California was next on the list for opportunities, with 9 percent of U.S. jobs and mean salaries of $24.58 per hour, or $51,130 per year. The highest pay was in Connecticut, at an average $25.49 per hour, or $53,010 per year, in 2011. Nevada followed with a mean wage of $25.13 per hour, or $52,270 per year. Texas offered the most jobs for LVNs -- almost 10 percent of the total jobs in the country -- and paid a mean $20.32 per hour, or $42,260 per year, according to the 2011 BLS statistics.

The latest data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics shows that the average annual salary for a LPN or LVN working in the United States is $42,400. This works out at $20.30 per hour, $815 per week and $3,533 per month. Look at the table below to see how this compares with the national average wage.

Hourly. Licensed Practical and Licensed Vocational Nurses median salary is $19.79 per hour. The lowest 10% earn $14.74 per hour and those in the upper 10% earn more than $27.00 per hour. Annually. On an annual basis the median Licensed Practical and Licensed Vocational Nurses salary is $41,150. The lowest 10% earn $30,650 per year while the upper 10% earn more than $57,000 per year.

According to figures released in May 2011 by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the average hourly wage for LPNs across the country in 2010 was $20.21 per hour, which for full-time hours works out to $42,040 per year. Entry-level wages can be much lower.

(United States). Licensed Vocational Nurses in the United States pull down an average of $19.72 per hour. The bottom of the pay range sits near $15.29 per hour, and the top verges on $25.41. The average worker who claims fewer than five years of experience earns around $40K. In contrast, however, individuals who report five to 10 years in this occupation see a much larger median of $44K. After working for 10 to 20 years, Licensed Vocational Nurses make a median salary of $45K.

Mean Annual LVN Salary. The average annual licensed vocational nurse salary is $42,910. The average salary is calculated by adding all the wages within the occupation and dividing that value by the total number of workers in this profession. The lowest 10% of licensed vocational nurse salaries are less than $31,300.

California and National Pay. LVNs held 61,050 jobs in California in 2013, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics. Their average hourly pay was $24.91, for an equivalent full-time annual wage of $51,800. The average pay for LVNs and LPNs nationwide was $20.63 per hour, or $42,910 annually in 2013. The top-paying state was Connecticut, where wages averaged $26.30 hourly, or $54,690 annually. As of 2012, approximately 80 percent of LVNs and LPNs nationwide worked full time, according to the BLS
